awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase I:  A Manufacturing Monitoring System Using Sound Spectrograms and Artificial Intelligence
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project is to improve manufacturing performance at decreased costs.  The project will develop a smart internal sound sensor- and artificial intelligence (AI)-based machine and process monitoring system as a simple plug-and-play edge device. It aims to be a low-cost, versatile, and customizable solution for a wide range of equipment and devices on production floors. This technology can significantly reduce the product defect rate, improve product quality, prolong machine life, increase the overall equipment effectiveness, and enable better human decisions. While this monitoring system can be deployed by any new/modern manufacturers, small and mid-sized enterprise (SME) companies can retrofit legacy equipment/ devices for understanding their machines, process behaviors, timely maintenance, and remaining life, etc. 

The proposed project is a stethoscope-like sensor that captures internal sounds across many frequencies without contamination from external factory sounds.  To interpret the captured sounds into useful information for dashboard publishing in terms of machine/process events (anomaly, situation, downtime, etc.), this project is developing AI-based sound classification or ‘machine speech’ recognition techniques. The sound data can be wirelessly acquired and processed, enabling a device for non-invasive application on the outside of  target equipment.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
At Maijker Corp, based on our innovative stethoscope-like internal sound sensor, we are developing a unique smart machine and process monitoring system that can be a non-invasive plug-and-play device as a simple and flexible solution and be easily customized for most of the machines and equipment in operation on production floors. With the NSF SBIR Phase I funding support (Award No. 2126939), we approached both on the hardware and software development tasks. We designed a prototype for testing it like a minimum viable product (MVP), developed artificial intelligence (AI) machine learning based 'machine speech' recognition techniques for different situations and machines, and deployed and tested the prototype in lab and real industry environments (as proof-of-concept) that help eliminate technical risks.

The developed prototype is found to be functional as a non-invasive plug-and-play product. It also stayed at the installed position for 5 months of testing period with no penetration of oil/grease, dirt/debris, external noises, etc. at the sensor-machine body interface, and can limit external noise transmission at mechanical junctions between the subsystems. The monitoring system responded well against all different equipment including, computer numerical control (CNC) machines, pipe bending and cutting machine, fiber laser cutting machine, automotive engines, pump. The developed software and data architecture are proven to be effective to support data acquisition and access (local and cloud) for processing (machine learning, data analytics, testing, etc.). Interestingly, some machine events like on/off, active/idle statuses of CNC machines can be defined based on thresholds of sound amplitudes (not requiring ML), which can be a low-cost solution for numerous equipment. Machine utilization time estimated by the system is found to be very close with a standard controller (Fanuc Focus). As machine speech recognition technique, AI machine learning models developed based on sound mel-spectrograms predicted process events at or more than 95% accuracy for most cases. This success can accelerate the development of our technology and allow complex classifications of machine events and processes. Process anomalies were also detected while testing automotive engines and CNC machine warm-up cycles.

During our Phase I customer discovery ('Beat-the-odds' bootcamp), we interviewed personnel from 35 companies in different sectors of manufacturing and attended industry tradeshows including Westec/AeroDef held in Long Beach, CA in November 2021. We discovered three key insights: i) Legacy Machines will exist for decades, but they are ignored in manufactures' digital transformation efforts, ii) Despite multiple industry survey reports indicating that more than 60% of Manufacturers implemented IIoT, only 15% of the manufacturers have had full adoption of Machine Monitoring on Factory Floors due to many limitations related mainly to complex applicability and high investments, and iii) There is a large potential market in the field of manufacturing automation for suitable monitoring device(s) that is to monitor missing assets and detect anomalies for predictive maintenance in plants. The phase I findings suggest that our unique smart monitoring technology has potentials to address these issues/demands.

In this proof-of-concept stage, we presented our technology in two international conferences including: i) The American Society of Mechanical Engineers (ASME)-sponsored Manufacturing Science and Engineering (MSEC) and The Society of Manufacturing Engineers (SME)-sponsored North American Manufacturing Research Conference (NAMRC) held at Purdue University in West Lafayette, IN in June 2022 (collocated), and ii) The International Manufacturing Trade Show (IMTS) held in Chicago, IL in September 2022. Many companies and engineers/scientists are interested to deploy this unique sensor system. Further, we presented our product and demo at the WHIN (Wabash Heartland Innovation Network) Manufacturing Summit at the Purdue In-Mac (Indiana Manufacturing Competitiveness Center) in May 2022. We collaborated with the Purdue University through a course project ME 597 Industrial IoT Implementation for Smart Manufacturing and supervised several undergrad and grad level students to learn about the technology, deploy and test in different industries. 

To date, regarding IP (intellectual property), one invention disclosure is produced within the company. One patent, one conference presentation and one journal paper are in development.  

Overall, this monitoring technology addresses the manufacturing and digitalization needs of U.S. enterprises/ factories with improved manufacturing monitoring and automation activities. It can enhance machine and its associated process monitoring and eventually the machine performance. Thus, it can significantly improve machine visibility, reduce defect rate, improve quality, prolong machine life, increase the OEE (overall equipment effectiveness), and enable better human decisions. The technology and its analyzed data can be used to educate and train students and trainees on manufacturing processes, machinery mechanisms, use of machine learning for manufacturing, and machine maintenance. We received high interests from partners to adopting our technology which will strengthen US machining monitoring industry and job market by applying our technology to different industries.

In conclusion, our monitoring system has shown huge potentials that can be useful for SMEs (small- and mid-sized enterprises), large manufacturers, and machine builders for their smart factory system development efforts.

 


Last Modified: 11/28/2022
Modified by: Chandra Nath

Images (1 of )
  • Non-Invasive IoT Device for Machine Status/Condition/Heath Monitoring, like a doctor examining a patient.
    Maijker Corp. (Left image is from a public domain)
    Copyrighted
    Chandra Nath
    Monitoring Technology - Summary
  • Non-invasive plug-and-play sensor prototype is installed at different locations (vertical wall, downside base surface, and spindle) on a CNC Milling to collect machine status information. Propagated sounds through machine structures are useful to identify machine statuses, anomaly, etc.
    Maijker Corp.
    Copyrighted
    Chandra Nath
    Sensor Prototype - Lab Test on a CNC Machine
  • Sounds of a CNC tool grinder in different forms - raw wav amplitude, mel-frequency spectrum, RMS, P-P values. Duration: 5 hr 21 min 21 sec (3 cycles + idle time)Grinding processes: Ready/Idle, rapid move, Prep Wheel grinding, Fluting Wheel grinding, Ball Gash grinding, Ball OD grinding
    Maijker Corp.
    Copyrighted
    Chandra Nath
    Sound Information of Process Events or Cycles of a CNC Tool Grinder
  • Machine utilization time (hrs and %) estimated by the internal sound data and given by a standard machine controller show a good match (with around 5% error) for more than 2 months. Maijker's internal sound-based monitoring system shows its potential in this early stage testing.
    Maijker Corp.
    Copyrighted
    Chandra Nath
    Machine Utilization Report: Internal Sound Sensor vs. a Standard Machine Controller
  • Training and Validation accuracy predicted for unseen sound data of a CNC tool (Duration: 5 hr 21 min 21 sec (3 cycles + idle time)) using AI Machine Learning model (Machine Speech Recognition Technique)
    Maijker Corp.
    Copyrighted
    Chandra Nath
    Training and Validation accuracy using internal sound data
  • Sound Information (Raw timeseries and STFT) of Process Events or Cycles of a Pipe Bending and Cutting Machine - Three internal sound sensors at three different locations for corresponding process information. One external mic used in the main bed shows poor process monitoring information.
    Maijker Corp.
    Copyrighted
    Chandra Nath
    Sound Information of a Pipe Bending and Cutting Machine
